ai-mn48:1.2_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-mn48:2.1_0: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambi were arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-mn48:2.2_0: They couldn’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor could they convince each other or be convinced.
ai-mn48:3.1_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn48:3.2_0: “Sir, Kosambi, who are arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words: they don’t persuade each other or allow each other with barbed words.”
ai-mn48:4.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed a certain monk, (saying):
ai-mn48:4.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell those mendicants that
ai-mn48:4.4_1: and after going, he said this to those monks:
ai-mn48:4.6_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn48:4.6_2: They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
ai-mn48:4.7_0: “Is it really true, mendicants, that you have been arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words?
ai-mn48:4.8_0: And that you can’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor can you convince each other or be convinced?”
ai-mn48:5.2_0: When you’re arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
ai-mn48:5.2_1: and mind, both in public and in private.”
ai-mn48:5.4_0: “So it seems that when you’re arguing you are not treating each other with kindness.
ai-mn48:5.4_1: there is no mental deeds, there is no hostilement in the spiritual life,
ai-mn48:5.5_0: So what exactly do you know and see, you foolish men, that you behave in such a way?
ai-mn48:5.6_0: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
ai-mn48:6.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn48:6.2_0: “Mendicants, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-mn48:6.4_0: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
ai-mn48:6.5_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.6_0: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness ...
ai-mn48:6.7_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.8_0: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness ...
ai-mn48:6.9_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.10_0: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.
ai-mn48:6.11_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.12_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion. ...
ai-mn48:6.13_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
ai-mn48:6.14_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-mn48:6.15_0: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

ai-mn48:7.1_0: Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
ai-mn48:7.2_0: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
ai-mn48:7.3_0: In the same way, these six warm-hearted qualities is the chief, the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-mn48:8.1_0: And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering?
ai-mn48:8.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
ai-mn48:8.3_0: ‘Is there anything that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see?’
ai-mn48:8.4_0: If a mendicant is overcome and mired in sensual desire,
ai-mn48:8.9_0: If a mendicant’s mind is full of thought about this world, they think:
ai-mn48:8.10_0: If a mendicant’s mind is full of thought about others,
ai-mn48:8.11_0: If a mendicant is arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with their minds.
ai-mn48:8.13_0: ‘There is nothing that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see.
ai-mn48:8.14_0: My mind is properly disposed for awakening to the truths.’
ai-mn48:8.15_0: This is the first knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is not shared with ordinary people.

ai-mn48:9.4_0: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, I personally gain serenity and quenching.’
ai-mn48:10.2_0: ‘Is there any other ascetic or brahmin elsewhere who has the same kind of view that I have?’
ai-mn48:10.4_0: ‘There are no ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have.’

ai-mn48:11.3_0: And what, mendicants, is the nature of a person accomplished in view?
ai-mn48:11.4_0: This is the nature of a person accomplished in view.

ai-mn48:13.2_0: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
ai-mn48:13.3_0: And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view?
ai-mn48:13.4_0: This strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they listen to the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
ai-mn48:13.6_0: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
ai-mn48:14.2_0: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
ai-mn48:14.3_0: And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view?
ai-mn48:14.4_0: The strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they find joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
ai-mn48:14.6_0: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
ai-mn48:15.1_0: When a noble disciple has these seven factors, they have properly investigated their own nature with respect to the realization of the fruit of stream-entry.
ai-mn48:15.2_0: A noble disciple with these seven factors has the fruit of stream-entry.”
ai-mn48:15.3_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn48:15.4_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn48:15.5_0: The eighth chapter on those from Kosambī is finished.
